Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Control of Reconfigurable Microgrids with Significant Renewable Power Sources

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research project is to develop a modeling and control framework to support a reconfigurable topology for electrical power microgrids that includes distributed sources or loads such as wind turbines, micro generators, and plug-in electric vehicles. The system ensures stable and efficient operation. The topology uses a decentralized optimal control framework to maximize efficiency with minimal communication among the microgrid components; a a way to assess stability of the microgrid as components such as wind turbines switch on and off; and a scalable, low-order modeling approach for the model-based control framework.

If successful, the results of this research will support the adoption of reconfigurable microgrids as one way to increase plug-in vehicles and renewable resources in the energy portfolio of the future. Also, this research is developing fundamental knowledge on decentralized optimal control, stability in mode-switching systems, and modeling and identification have wide application beyond electrical grids, such as autonomous robotic swarms and large scale computer networks. The research results will be disseminated widely to the scientific community through publications; to graduate and undergraduate students through new courses and course modules; to over 40 industry partners through workshops, seminars, and short courses; to high school students and teachers through summer camps; and to K-12 students through two museum exhibits. The activities of this award will also provide underrepresented minorities with opportunities to participate in engineering research in both graduate and undergraduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has established a modeling framework to describe transient voltage and frequency dynamics of microgrids.  The model makes it possible for multiple sources of varying types of generators (conventional synchronous generators such as steam turbine generators, or inverter-connected generators such as wind turbines and solar cells) to be easily interconnected. This model is also of the state space form, which facilitates the implementation and comparison of different multi-input multi-output (MIMO) control strategies.

Optimal control strategies, including linear quadratic regulator and H-infinity control, have been explored and applied to the microgrid model. Centralized and decentralized controllers have been developed for the microgrid. In order to maintain its resilience when disaster happens and loss of communication occurs, decentralized or distributed control structure is preferred. A decentralized H-infinity MIMO controller for both microgrid voltage and frequency has been developed. Simulation results show the controller’s effectiveness on maintaining a good performance when facing microgrid disturbances and sudden connection or disconnection of the inverter-interfaced energy resources.

This control method operates entirely with local measurements, allowing for scalability in larger networks. As distributed generation continues to grow, especially with the forecasted expansion of renewable energy, inverter-based generators will comprise a larger portion of power sources. The control method presented is a robust and scalable method to control inverter-interfaced sources, and is well-suited for the expansion of microgrids..

This research has resulted in four peer-reviewed conference proceedings, one journal paper to be submitted, and one poster presentation. Five graduate students and one undergraduate student have been trained while working on this project. They have gained expertise on advancing control theorem and technology development. They are inspired by the challenges arising from this project and are enthusiastic for further science and technology explorations. The PI has helped organize a K-12 STEM summer camp for four years as a part of outreach effort. The students were exposed to topics including wind turbine operation, solar energy generation and PEM fuel cell vehicles. The integration of lecture, demonstration and hands-on experience has provided an effective way to allow young students to gain knowledge about renewable energy sources and their associated technologies.
